Award.AwardTitle: Probing Physical Conditions in Blazars (Active Galaxies) through Time-Dependent Optical Light
Award.AbstractNarration:
Blazars are the ultra-luminous, highly-variable hearts of galaxies. Physicians have tools to study how the human heart varies, and that variability is used to understand how the heart works. Similarly, astronomers have tools to study how blazars vary, and that variability is used to understand how blazars work. The team will use telescopes in Arizona to observe blazars at optical wavelengths. They will look for minute-to-minute changes in the blazars' brightness and polarization. They will also look for night-to-night changes in the blazars' emission lines. These changes will be compared to predictions from the team's models. Senior team members will train junior members. Navajo-Hopi students from Arizona schools will visit the telescopes. While there, they will be able to witness the changes in the blazars.

The team will investigate the physical processes responsible for blazars' time variability. The team's goals are to use observations and models to examine (1) if particles are accelerated via shocks or magnetic reconnection; (2) if very rapid variability on parsec scales is caused by turbulence or magnetic reconnection; and (3) if gamma-rays can be generated on parsec scales via the seed photons from nearby emission-line gas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The project involved observational and theoretical studies of a type of active galactic nucleus (AGN) called "blazars." In an AGN, a black hole with mass between about 1 million and 10 billion times the Sun's mass resides at the center of a galaxy and actively accretes gaseous matter from its surroundings. The gas orbits the black hole but also gradually falls toward it, becoming so hot that the atoms lose some of their electrons to become ionized. Magnetic fields are mixed with the ionized gas to form a state of matter called a "plasma." As the plasma falls toward the black hole's event horizon, it swirls around the black hole, twisting the magnetic fields into a spiral pattern. As is the case for a twisted wire, this causes a spring-like action that ejects jets of high-energy particles and magnetic fields in opposite directions along the rotational poles of the system. (The rest of the plasma falls into the black hole.) The plasma is propelled down the jet at nearly light speed. If one of the jets points within a few degree of our line of sight, we see the blazar phenomenon. The near-light speed causes the light from the plasma to be beamed into our direction and creates the illusion that events happen faster than is actually the case. Bright spots in the jet can appear to move faster than light, and outbursts ("flares") of radio, infrared, visible, ultraviolet, X-ray, and gamma-ray light are seen that last for times that can be as short as about 10 minutes.

The primary goals of the project were to understand how flares of visible and gamma-ray light occur in blazars. In order to accomplish this, the investigators observed the time-variable polarization (ordering of the light that is related to the magnetic field geometry), emission-line spectra, and images of the light from blazars. The observational results were compared with those of the investigators' theoretical simulations. During the project, the investigators observed 28 one-week sessions at the 1.8-meter-diameter Perkins Telescope in Flagstaff, Arizona. The purpose was to follow changes in the polarization of visible light. The observations discovered strong, time-variable color dependence of the polarization of optical light from blazars during flares. This behavior, which has not been observed previously, strongly favors a turbulent magnetic field that is largely responsible for the chaotic behavior of blazars.

The investigators also observed on 30 nights at Lowell Observatory's 4.3-meter-diameter Lowell Discovery Telescope (LDT), plus 10 2-hour target-of-opportunity observations of individual blazars that were flaring at optical and gamma-ray frequencies. Flares of gamma-ray light are caused by high-energy electrons in blazar jets colliding with "seed" photons and knocking them up to higher energies. Many of the gamma-ray flares, however, have been found to take place 10 or more light-years from the black hole, where it is difficult to understand where a sufficient high density of seed photons could originate. One proposal is that they come from a previously unknown group of hot clouds just outside the jet. Observations of blazars with the LDT found that a group of emission lines from iron ions became stronger during bright optical and gamma-ray flares, as this hypothesis predicted.

The investigators were active members of the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) imaging team that made images of the region surrounding the black hole at the center of the galaxy M87. The images indeed revealed the predicted black hole shadow, confirming that the event horizon exists. 

Awards bestowed upon the Event Horizon Telescope Collaboration, which includes the investigators, for imaging of the "black hole shadow" surrounding the super-massive black hole at the center of the galaxy M87, include:2019 National Science Foundation Diamond Achievement Award (inaugural award), the 2020 Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics2020, and the Bruno Rossi Prize.

The multi-color optical polarization data collected at the Perkins Telescope have been made publicly available at a web page devoted to the project at URL www.bu.edu/blazars/mobpol/mobpol.html. The investigators reported the findings of time-variable, color-dependent polarization at five conferences, and the time-variable emission lines at two conferences. They have published (as authors or co-authors) 29 papers in refereed scientific journals based on the results of the project. The investigators and their students discussed the results of the project at 8 scientific conferences. 

Broader Impacts:

During the project, the investigators trained 4 graduate students, 6 undergraduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher, in techniques related to complex observations, data analysis, and theoretical interpretation of phenomena related to blazars.

The PI gave brief presentations of the M87 results to three undergraduate classes. The PI and co-I gave 3 presentations at libraries based on the results of the project. The talks were well-attended by 30-40 people per event. The PI completed an electronic textbook on cosmology and made it publicly available at no cost on the investigators' website.
